Buddha's disciple!
If there are beings who, for the sake of seeking bodhi, cultivate practices and wish for constant peace and happiness, they should cultivate the mind of loving-kindness to subdue themselves.

Cultivating in this way, in every thought, always fully practicing the six perfections, one can quickly attain the stages of patience, quickly perfect unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, be endowed with the ten powers, the four fearlessnesses, the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha, the thirty-two marks, and the eighty minor characteristics, and adorn one's body with the most supreme merits;
Dwelling eternally in peace and happiness until the end of the future;
And also able to eliminate all sentient beings' heavy karmic hindrances from beginningless time.
Buddha's disciple!

If bodhisattvas cultivate the mind of loving-kindness, they should be in a secluded and quiet place, with pure faith gather all mental factors, and contemplate the upper and lower parts of the body, all of which are aggregates of dust, formed by the combination of earth, water, fire, and wind;
They should further contemplate that within each and every dust particle, there is space;
All these spaces are characterized by being able to accommodate;
Moreover, one should visualize those dust motes as pure and clear, externally like lapis lazuli, internally like purple gold, wondrously adorned, soft and fragrant;
One should also contemplate the sentient beings in all worlds, the limbs and joints of each sentient being, and the dust motes in each limb and joint, all being like this.

If the bodhisattvas have made such a resolute understanding of their own bodies, the bodies of others, and all sentient beings, they should further visualize the dust motes in their own bodies, with a buddha land in each dust mote;

In it, the palaces are made of lapis lazuli, the gates are of white silver, the pillars are of gold, it is vast and lofty, with radiant light penetrating everywhere, jeweled halls are arranged in between, and jeweled walls surround it, with jeweled pavilions and towers distributed here and there;
In each of them there are jeweled beds of the heavens, with multiple layers of fine cushions spread upon them;
There are also innumerable excellent gardens and groves, surrounding and adorning it;

In the garden, there are all bathing pools, all with embankments made of the seven treasures, golden railings surrounding the four sides, long flowing clear springs leading into them, fragrant powders as mud, with golden sand interspersed, filled with the eight virtues of water, clear and still;
Pundarika flowers, utpala flowers, kumuda flowers, and padma flowers, all in full bloom, covering the surface;
On the four sides of the pools, there are many jeweled trees, with pearls as flowers, their luster luxuriant;
Their fruits are ripe, with fragrance and flavor complete. Under the trees, heavenly jeweled seats are placed;
In front of each seat, jeweled vessels are arranged in rows, filled with nectar and delicious food.
One should further visualize all the Buddha lands in this way, with lapis lazuli as their ground, adorned with the marvelous seven treasures;

In these lands, the dust is pure and fine, like heavenly jewels, its light shining brightly like the rising sun, its color beautiful like JambÅ«nada gold, its fragrance pervasive like the sandalwood of the Uragas, its texture soft like the cloth of KÄtyÄyana, and its touch on the body able to bring joy.
Having contemplated thus, one should then imagine that all sentient beings in all worlds in the east come to enter the palaces of my buddha-lands;
in the south, west, north, the four intermediate directions, and above and below, all sentient beings in those worlds are also like this.

One should further imagine that all sentient beings in the six destinies are the same in deportment, similar in appearance, their bodies soft and always fragrant, with the characteristics of a great man, fully adorned, free from suffering and distress, and experiencing heavenly bliss.
If these sentient beings needed clothing or ornaments, they would immediately go to the foot of the Kalpa tree, and according to their needs, they would obtain various implements for adornment;

It was like the Heaven of Freely Partaking of the Pleasures Created in Other Heavens. Moreover, fragrant breezes came from the eight directions. When the breezes touched their bodies, they made their minds feel happy. There were various musical instruments that no one played, but they turned and moved along with the wind, producing wonderful sounds.

These sentient beings, whether in palaces, strolling in gardens, eating heavenly delicacies, holding jeweled vessels and drinking nectar, or sitting on lotus pedestals, their bodies adorned with necklaces hanging on both sides, their wealth and treasures filling up, their various implements complete, according to their preferences, enjoying various pleasures, their faces full of joy, their bodies and minds feeling at ease, their bodies always free from illness, their prime-aged good looks not aging or dying, their merits and powers all being of the same kind;
Those who are not controlled by others, who are able to destroy lust, anger, and ignorance, will attain enlightenment and ultimately attain peace and happiness.
Buddha's disciple!

If one who cultivates loving-kindness sees that one sentient being among these sentient beings goes against oneself, and one's mind does not give rise to love and affection upon contemplating this, one should deeply contemplate with wisdom: 'In my past lives, I definitely created heavy karmic hindrances towards this person;
Because of this cause, it is now hindering my enlightenment;
If I do not give rise to joy towards this person, then I should not benefit all other sentient beings.'
Why is this?
Because from beginningless time in the cycle of birth and death, there is not a single sentient being who has not harmed me in the past;
If I do not give rise to compassion towards this sentient being, then I should also be the same towards all others.
I now universally benefit all sentient beings, and therefore I must have loving-kindness and compassion for them.

Moreover, one should contemplate that the causes and conditions of anger can cause sentient beings to fall into hell, and if one harbors resentment, one will definitely be reborn as a poisonous snake in the future;
If I receive this retribution in the future, I should make that person feel deeply happy.
Therefore, one should abandon all thoughts of anger and resentment.
If I have much anger and resentment, the World-Honored Buddhas of the present in the ten directions should all see me and think like this:
'How can this person, who wishes to seek enlightenment, give rise to anger and resentment?
Because of anger and resentment, this foolish person cannot liberate themselves from their own suffering, so how can they save all sentient beings?'
Beings with much anger, wherever they are born, the bodies they receive are filled with evil and poison;
Therefore, one should cultivate a compassionate mind, forever free from anger and resentment, and equally benefit and bring peace and happiness to all sentient beings.

golden vessels adorned with the seven treasures, the radiance of the vessels like the sun and moon, their fragrance like that of black agarwood, filled with nectar, used to make offerings to the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and the assembly of Sravakas, the Bodhisattvas and Arhats all playing happily in the TathÄgata's supreme Dharma;

One should further contemplate that all sentient beings are seated in front of the Buddhas, and the Buddhas expound to them the practice of cultivating loving-kindness, just as I am now cultivating it. The sound of their words is beautiful and delightful, bringing the utmost bliss to all sentient beings.
It is like a person who obtains nectar to drink, and by washing and bathing with it, they relieve their fatigue and suffering, and their body and spirit are refreshed.
This is also like that. By the Dharma moistening their minds, they extinguish all afflictions, and their body and mind are tranquil, forever attaining peace and bliss.

One should further contemplate that all the jeweled banners, flags, canopies, garments, and so forth, have dust particles that are radiant and bright, surpassing the sun, soft and smooth to the touch like the body of a celestial being, emitting a fragrance like that of ox-head sandalwood, their color pure like vaiá¸Å«rya jewels, and all images are reflected within them.

One should further contemplate that all sentient beings that I think of are empty of self-nature, like a dream, an illusion, a mirage, or a hallucination;
all buddhas are also like this, their intrinsic nature is all empty and originally without self.
Ordinary people, lacking wisdom, falsely grasp at the self-nature of self, and therefore cannot escape birth and death.

One should further contemplate that the essence and characteristics of all dharmas are subtle and all empty and quiescent. Ordinary people, due to their own discrimination, give rise to various realms and are still bound by their own discrimination. As long as they have not yet understood the self-nature of the mind, for that long they are like in a dream, falsely attached to various realms.
One should further contemplate that all three realms are empty, and emptiness does not obstruct emptiness. One's present compassionate mind is still narrow.

One should also reflect that just as the nature of all sentient beings and all Buddhas is empty and without self, one should know that one's own body is also like this, and all lands are also only thoughts.

Having understood this, one should further contemplate that in each and every particle of dust, there are the lands of the Buddhas of the three times. These lands are supremely pure, surpassing the Buddha lands of the past, and are fully endowed with the adornments of the Buddhas and sentient beings of the three times.

The number of kalpas in the three times enters a single thought. In each thought, Buddhas of the three times sit in all places, universally appearing before all sentient beings. They may enter meditation, expound the wonderful Dharma, savor fine food, or drink sweet dew. In front of each Buddha, Bodhisattvas and Arhats of the three times sit surrounded. The bliss of the three times fills their bodies.
One also sees one's own body in the presence of the Buddhas, receiving such bliss of the three times.

One should further contemplate, in each thought, one's body of the three times, each holding immeasurable excellent offerings, making offerings to all Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and Shravakas, and bestowing them upon the various kinds of sentient beings.

In each and every thought, from his body emerged various fragrant clouds, and within the clouds were innumerable jeweled canopies, adorned and draped over all the Buddha TathÄgatas, Bodhisattvas, ÅšrÄvakas, and the beings of the six destinies.

Buddha's disciple!
It is like a bhiká¹£u entering the universal concentration, understanding all things as earth, water, fire, and wind, using such understanding to control his mind;
The person cultivating kindness is also like this, adorning and controlling with the superior understanding of kindness.
One should further contemplate, The peace and happiness I now bestow upon sentient beings is merely an idea, like an illusion, like a transformation.
It is like a magician creating illusory things. I am also like this, bestowing various peace and happiness upon sentient beings.
Moreover, just as illusory objects have no intrinsic nature, all sentient beings are also like this, originally having no nature of self or what belongs to self.
Moreover, it is like a thirsty deer, mistakenly giving rise to the thought of water in a mirage, strenuously pursuing it. One should know that my mind practicing kindness is also like this.
Moreover, just as water cannot be obtained in a mirage, all dharmas are also like this, having no nature of self.

It is also like seeing various things in a dream, the dreaming mind discriminating them as real things, but when one awakens, there is nothing to be found. One should know that all dharmas are also like this.

It is like a person with blurred vision seeing various things in the clear sky and taking them to be real. Later, that person obtains the agada medicine, and when the blurred vision is cured, all the things seen disappear.
In the same way, sentient beings, due to the views of self and extremes, have the notion of self. If they obtain the medicine of wisdom and eliminate these views, the notion of self will also cease.
Therefore, I should cultivate loving-kindness in this way, like awakening from a dream, free from self and what belongs to self.

Buddha's disciples should know that those who cultivate loving-kindness, as long as they are unable to be free from discrimination and unable to avoid giving rise to the views of self and what belongs to self, will always obtain the six kinds of blessings of the Brahma Heaven;

If one abandons discrimination and is free from self and grasping, this is called vast compassion. All karmic hindrances accumulated from the past will be eliminated, and one will soon realize supreme enlightenment.
Buddha's disciple!
All bodhisattvas should cultivate the compassionate mind in this way. You who cultivate compassion are called the compassionate ones.
Buddha's disciple!

If good men and good women who hear this Sutra on Cultivating Compassion are able to eliminate all karmic hindrances accumulated from beginningless time, free themselves from various illnesses and calamities, and become loved and respected by all people, then whether in the present or at the time of death, they will surely get to see the Buddhas of the ten directions, receive the prediction of supreme perfect enlightenment, attain samÄdhi, attain the acceptance of the Dharma, or enter the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gate. It is just like a person who fills the three realms with the seven treasures and offers them to the Tathagatas three times a day for an entire eon. One should know that the merit of that person is also like this;
How much more so for those who cultivate and practice it?
Even if innumerable Buddha Tathagatas were to speak of its merits for an eon, they would still be unable to exhaust it.

After the Buddha spoke this sutra, Maitreya Bodhisattva-mahasattva and the Brahma assemblies from the lands of the ten directions all greatly rejoiced, and with faith and understanding they upheld and practiced it.
